Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Centralized planning of electricity generation in the New Zealand electricity market
Award.AbstractNarration:
Efficiently generating electricity is a complex task, made more complex as renewable resources are added, new companies enter the market, and there is more focus on reducing greenhouse gas emissions. New models better equipped to handle these emerging complexities need to be developed. This project will develop such a model, which will include scheduling of both thermal and hydro resources under different market conditions, for the New Zealand electricity market. This work will be completed in collaboration with Dr. Andy Philpott, at the University of Auckland. A better understanding of the interplay between these resources can lead to more reliable systems, lower costs, and greater utilization of sustainable technologies. Although the New Zealand electricity market is unique in its operation and available resources, the mathematical techniques are universal. Models that will be developed are applicable to not only other similar systems, but to regional electricity markets in general.

In particular, this research will focus on the short-term scheduling of thermal and hydro resources in centralized and decentralized contexts. These models will include accurate representations of the cascading river-chain systems, which will be co-optimized with thermal generation for a day-ahead planning horizon. In such a model, both stochasticity of prices and renewable resource availability must be considered, which motivates the use of decomposition algorithms to exploit problem structure. The newly developed model will be compared to the self-dispatch system currently in place. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Royal Society of New Zealand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Have you ever wondered how your electricity is generated or how its price is determined? To study the effects of market forces on electricity generation in New Zealand, graduate student Amy Pielow of The Ohio State University researched the costs associated with centralized or decentralized coordination of electricity generators when demand is uncertain. The work was completed under the supervision of Dr. Andy Philpott and Dr. Golbon Zakeri at the University of Auckland.

The purpose of the project is to quantify different sources of inefficiency in electricity markets. Currently, markets function such that utilities submit bids—quantities of electricity they would be willing to produce at given prices—to as system operator who then determines the operation levels of generators to make supply equal demand. The offered prices are one source of potential inefficiency, should the companies exercise market power. Another flaw in electricity markets is the lack of complete information, as operating decisions must be made before demand is known.

Understanding how impactful these forces are on market outcomes helps system operators make better decisions and may even affect policy. Central coordination of resources may result in lower costs to consumers and less reliance on fossil fuels. As demand for electricity grows and becomes more variable, along with increased variability of supply, the market behavior analysis becomes even more important.

Several models were developed at the University of Auckland to capture these impacts, then further modified to focus on the fossil-fuel burning thermal generators.  Running the models and comparing the outcomes, in terms of costs and generation from different plants, estimates the costs of inefficiency. A case study was completed using historical data for that purpose. Comparing the perfect information solutions to the historical values gives a measure of total inefficiency. Whenever possible, it is best to use hydrological generation, as it is inexpensive and sustainable, so comparing results based on reduction of thermal generation is appropriate. Less thermal generation means more use of hydro resources. For the month of February 2009, perfect information results, on average, 12% less reliance on thermal generation, or 120 MW of power daily. Market power can account for up to an additional 95 MW of generation on average when isolated, and uncertainty of demand accounts for up to 103 MW of daily generation on average.
